fr:mainmatter.html:p: A simplicial set X is an \infty -category if it has the extension property against the inner horn inclusions \Lambda ^n_i \to \Delta ^n, where 0 < i < n.

Given a \infty -category X, the sub-simplicial set with the same objects, only equivalences as edges and all valid higher simplices is called the core of the \infty -category, denoted \operatorname {core}(X). This is an \infty -groupoid.

Suppose a map f of simplicial sets has the right lifting property against all inner horn inclusions \Lambda ^n_i \hookrightarrow \Delta ^n, where n \ge 1 and 0 < i < n, then we say f is an inner fibration. If we strengthen the condition to 0 \le i < n, then we get the left fibration. Similarly for right fibrations. If we allow 0 \le i \le n, then we get a Kan fibration. Hence, an \infty -category is the same as an inner fibration X \to 1. The same goes for a Kan complex.

The class of maps that have left lifting property against all inner fibrations is called inner anodyne. Similarly for left and right anodyne maps. For Kan fibrations, we use the unqualified phrase “anodyne map”. Obviously we have inner anodyne maps contained in both left and right anodyne maps, which in turn are contained in anodyne maps. They are all monomorphisms.
Given two \infty -categories X, Y, their join X \star Y is still an \infty -category.

The vertices of X \star Y is given by X_0 \sqcup Y_0. Consider a horn \Lambda ^n_i. Suppose its vertices lie entirely within X_0, then all its higher simplices are in X too, so we can fill the horn within X. Similarly for Y.

For the other cases, notice that an edge can only go from X to Y and not backwards. As long as (n, i) \ne (2, 0), (2, 2) — which does not occur since we only need inner horns — we know the first k vertices are in X and the rest are in Y, and we can restrict the horn along \Delta ^{ \{0, \dots , k-1\} } \hookrightarrow \Lambda ^n_i and \Delta ^{ \{k, \dots , n\} } \hookrightarrow \Lambda ^n_i. From this we can construct the simplex \Delta ^n \to X \star Y by definition of the join.

Given a simplicial set Y and a vertex p : 1 \to Y, we define the slice simplicial set Y_{/p} by the universal property that maps K \to Y_{/p} are in natural bijection with maps K^{\triangleright } \to Y from the cocone such that the cocone point is mapped to p.

More generally, given simplicial sets X, Y and a map p : X \to Y, the slice simplicial set Y_{/p} is defined by the universal property that maps K \to Y_{/p} is in bijection with maps K \star X \to Y such that the restriction X \hookrightarrow K \star X \to Y is p.
Dually, we can define coslice simplicial sets Y_{p/} using cones K^{\triangleleft } \to Y. When Y is an \infty -category, we also call them overcategories and undercategories.
A \infty -groupoid is a \infty -category with all arrows being equivalences. In other words, it is a \infty -category X such that \operatorname {ho} X is a groupoid.

fr:title.text: \infty -groupoids are the same as Kan complexes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: \infty -groupoids are the same as Kan complexes

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A simplicial set is an \infty -groupoid iff it is a Kan complex.

Given an \infty -category X, we can extend along inner horn inclusions \Lambda ^n_i \hookrightarrow \Delta ^n, where 0 < i < n. So to prove it is a Kan complex, we need to additionally prove the extension property for i = 0 (the left horn) and i = n (the right horn). Inspecting the cases where n = 2, we see that intuitively the left horn extension requires the leftmost arrow \Delta ^{\{0,1\}} \hookrightarrow \Delta ^n to be “invertible”. Dually for the right horn. We can propose a lemma.

An arrow f in an \infty -category X is an equivalence iff any left horn \Lambda ^n_0 \to X with the leftmost arrow \Delta ^{\{0,1\}} \subseteq \Lambda ^n_0 being f can be extended to \Delta ^n, where n \ge 2.

Given the definition of a slice of simplicial sets, we can reduce the n-simplices and left horns to a single arrow in a slice category. Consider the map q : X_{/\Delta ^{n-2}} \to X_{/\partial \Delta ^{n-2}}. A left horn is equivalent to a square

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Here the top arrow specifies the simplex spanning the vertices \{0, 2, 3, \dots , n\} = [n] \setminus 1, and the bottom arrow specifies all the simplex faces except [n] \setminus 0 and [n] \setminus 1. A solution to this lifting problem is equivalent to filling the required horn.

Performing this reduction allows us to remove all the consideration of higher simplices, because we can view the right arrow as a black box q : E \to B, and all the information we need is that the bottom arrow is an equivalence, and the right arrow is a right fibration.

To see that q is a right fibration, use the Joyal–Tierney calculus on joins and slices. Since X is an \infty -category, X \to 1 is an inner fibration. \partial \Delta ^{n-2} \to \Delta ^{n-2} is obviously a monomorphism. The pullback-power of them is isomorphic to q.

To see that the bottom arrow f' selects an equivalence in X_{/\partial \Delta ^k}, we first note that X_{/\partial \Delta ^{n-2}} \to X_{/\varnothing } = X, the functor that forgets the slicing and returns the underlying object, is also a right fibration in the same way as above. And the image of f' under this functor is f, which is an equivalence. The theorem now reduces to two facts about equivalences under right fibrations:

html:ul.html:li: If the image of an arrow under a right fibration is an equivalence, then the arrow itself is already an equivalence.
Given a right fibration q : E \to B, an equivalence f' in B and a lift of the left object (i.e. domain of the equivalence), there exists a compatible lift of f' under q.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: These can both be proven by elementary manipulations of lifting properties.

Now suppose X is an \infty -groupoid, a left horn \Lambda ^n_0 \to X can always be extended to \Delta ^n \to X, because all arrows, and hence the leftmost arrow in particular, are equivalences. Dually all the right horns can be extended. Therefore a \infty -groupoid is a Kan complex.

The other direction is easy. We consider the horns \Lambda ^2_i \hookrightarrow \Delta ^2 where i = 0, 2. Let the longest edge be the identity arrow. Then the extension property implies the other edge is invertible.

Given an \infty -category X, an arrow is an equivalence iff it is an isomorphism in the homotopy category. More concretely, there need to be left and right inverse arrows g_1, g_2 with two triangles witnessing f \mathbin {\circ } g_1 = \textrm {id} and g_2 \mathbin {\circ } f = \textrm {id} in the homotopy category.

Following the proof in group theory and 1-category theory, we see that we can take g_1 homotopic to g_2 (i.e. equal in the homotopy category) without loss of generality. But then the well-definedness of composition in the homotopy category implies g_1 \mathbin {\circ } f = \textrm {id} too.

Given an \infty -category X, we can alternatively define its homotopy category in this way: The objects are given by the vertices of X, the arrows are equivalence classes of edges, where two edges f, g : x \to y are equivalent if there is a 2-simplex x \xrightarrow {f} y = y with the long edge given by g.
There is a long list of things we need to do.

html:ul.html:li: We need to prove the given relation is indeed an equivalence.
We need to construct the composition operation.
We need to prove the composition is well-defined under the quotient.
We need to prove associativity and identity laws for the composition.
Finally, we need to prove the two constructions of homotopy category are equivalent. In fact, they are strictly isomorphic.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The identity arrow is given by the degenerate edge, and composition is given by the inner Kan extension against \Lambda ^2_1 \hookrightarrow \Delta ^2. Another Kan extension shows that this construction doesn’t depend on the choice of extensions: Suppose we have two possible compositions, being the upper edge and the long diagonal edge in the 3-simplex:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

\begin {tikzcd} x && z \\ & y && z \arrow ["{g \mathbin {\circ } f}", from=1-1, to=1-3] \arrow ["f"', from=1-1, to=2-2] \arrow [equals, from=1-3, to=2-4] \arrow ["g"', from=2-2, to=1-3] \arrow ["g"', from=2-2, to=2-4] \arrow [from=1-1, to=2-4] \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: By filling the upper-right triangle, we get the equivalence of the two arrows. The quotiented relation being an equivalence relation, and that composition respects it can also be proved similarly. The identity law \textrm {id} \mathbin {\circ } f = f is obvious and the other identity law is given by another Kan extension:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

\begin {tikzcd} x && y \\ & x && y \arrow ["f", from=1-1, to=1-3] \arrow [equals, from=1-1, to=2-2] \arrow [from=1-1, to=2-4] \arrow [equals, from=1-3, to=2-4] \arrow [from=2-2, to=1-3] \arrow ["f"', from=2-2, to=2-4] \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Here the long arrow is given by f \mathbin {\circ } \textrm {id}. All but the triangle on the top-right can be filled easily, and we fill in the last one via Kan extension, proving f is equivalent to f \mathbin {\circ } \textrm {id}.

As for associativity, consider this 3-simplex, with the long arrow given by h \mathbin {\circ } (g \mathbin {\circ } f). We can fill in the top-right triangle between f, h \mathbin {\circ } g and h \mathbin {\circ } (g \mathbin {\circ } f).

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

\begin {tikzcd} x && z \\ & y && w \arrow ["{g\mathbin {\circ } f}", from=1-1, to=1-3] \arrow ["f"', from=1-1, to=2-2] \arrow [from=1-1, to=2-4] \arrow ["h", from=1-3, to=2-4] \arrow [from=2-2, to=1-3] \arrow ["{h\mathbin {\circ } g}"', from=2-2, to=2-4] \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Now we can use the fact that the composition doesn’t depend on the choice of Kan extension to get the equality between h \mathbin {\circ } (g\mathbin {\circ } f) and (h\mathbin {\circ } g) \mathbin {\circ } f. We next need to prove the equivalence of this definition with the original definition of homotopy category. Let the new definition be temporarily denoted \operatorname {ho}' X.

To obtain a functor \operatorname {ho} X \to \operatorname {ho}' X, we need to prove that the composition indeed satisfies g \mathbin {\circ } f = h whenever there is a 2-simplex with these three edges. This is true because composition is independent of the choice of Kan extensions. The functor is obviously full and surjective on objects. For faithfulness, we have two strings of composable arrows, with a collection of triangles filling them. By performing induction on the length of these strings, we can compose the triangles together to prove the equivalence of their images in \operatorname {ho}' X.
